I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),  through  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian 
Nations  (ASEAN),  was  requested  to  provide  regional  technical  assistance  (TA)  support  to 
enhance  cooperation  among  the  region’s  equity  markets.  As  members  of  ASEAN,  Brunei 
Darussalam,  Indonesia,  Malaysia,  Philippines,  Singapore,  and  Thailand  are  committed  to 
greater cross-border cooperation to promote fair and equitable access to capital in the region 
(hereinafter referred to as “participating countries”).1 The Project will build on ASEAN initiatives 
and related ADB TA in this area.  2 The Design and Monitoring Framework is set forth in 
Appendix 1. 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The region’s capacity to secure and sustain strong economic growth depends on access 
to  capital  by  regional  enterprises  through  well  functioning  capital  markets.  Well-developed 
capital markets help reduce the overall cost of capital and dependency on bank financing. 
Access to capital by medium-sized enterprises in the region is limited because of the small size 
of most equity markets, market fragmentation, and constraints to raising capital across borders. 
Although  the  savings  rate  in  most  participating  countries’  economies  is  high,  financial 
intermediation is generally not efficient and capital tends to flow outside the region. Moreover, 
larger  enterprises  in  participating  countries  often  raise  capital  outside  the  region.  Lack  of 
effective cooperation among participating countries’ equity markets undermines the collective 
advantages of the region and makes it more vulnerable to international market and policy 
developments. 3     
 
3.  With  the  exception  of  Singapore,  the  region’s  equity  markets  operate  with  a  local 
emphasis.  There  are  significant  differences  in  legal  and  regulatory  regimes,  governance, 
openness to competition, size, number of listed issuers, volume of trading, role of contractual 
savings systems, extent of foreign listing, trading hours, and transaction costs. Total regional 
market capitalization of participating countries in 2004 was $616.5 billion, of which Singapore 
($218 billion), Malaysia ($182 billion) and Thailand ($115 billion) comprised the largest share. 
More than $4.3 billion of new capital was raised through initial public offerings, half of which was 
in Singapore ($2.2 billion), followed by Thailand ($982 million) and Malaysia ($874 million).4   
 
4.  National  governments  and  the  private  sector  in  participating  countries  have  taken 
initiatives since the 1997 Asian financial crisis to broaden and deepen local capital markets. 
Stock  exchanges  in  Malaysia,  the  Philippines,  and  Singapore  have  been  converted  from 
member-owned entities to for-profit corporations (demutualized), and are in the process of 
restructuring their operations.5 Markets have integrated horizontally6 (Malaysia, Philippines, and 
Singapore)  and  vertically7  (Malaysia  and  Singapore)  to  operate  more  efficiently  and  have 
introduced new products (Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand). Singapore has become a 
regional financial hub and has actively sought greater cooperation, including linkages, with other 
regional (Malaysia) and international (Australia, Japan, and US) markets. While equity markets

in  Malaysia  and  Thailand  have  grown  significantly,  systemic  constraints—including  poor 
governance  and  weak  enforcement  of  laws  and  regulations,  and  concentrated  share 
ownership—continue to undermine the development of the Indonesian and Philippine markets. 8  
 
5.  With respect to regulation, the Philippines and Singapore have significantly strengthened 
their legal and regulatory frameworks, and all participating countries have enhanced corporate 
governance, corporate disclosure and listing requirements. All capital market regulators in the 
participating countries are members of the International Organization of Securities Commissions 
(IOSCO) and have committed to full implementation of the IOSCO best practice principles and 
objectives of securities regulation. Stock exchanges in Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand have 
upgraded their trading platforms for equities to promote market liquidity and enhance trading 
efficiency.  Stock  exchanges  in  Indonesia,  Malaysia  and  Singapore  have  improved  their 
electronic  surveillance  systems  to  provide  greater  transparency  of  trading  activities.  Stock 
markets  in  the  participating  countries  have  improved  electronic  information  dissemination, 
including website dissemination of trading data, and company disclosures (e.g., quarterly and 
annual reports). 
  
6.  Through  ASEAN,  Southeast  Asian  countries  have  agreed  to  enhance  cross-border 
collaboration among regional capital markets, which is one of the four areas of cooperation 
under the ASEAN Roadmap for Financial and Monetary Integration, coordinated by a working 
committee on capital market development. The working committee aims to improve legal and 
regulatory cooperation and supervision through better coordination among regulatory authorities 
to address cross-border wrongdoing, detect unfair trading practices, and ensure fair treatment of 
shareholders  and  timely  disclosure  by  issuers.9  Singapore  is  a  signatory  to  an  IOSCO 
multilateral memorandum of understanding that provides for sharing of information with other 
signatories to support cross-border enforcement of securities wrongdoing. Other countries have 
entered into bilateral memoranda of understanding. Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia have 
formally  agreed  to  cooperate  with  each  other  with  respect  to  cross  border  enforcement. 
Indonesia and the Philippines reached a similar agreement.10  
 
7.  ASEAN has formed a task force to explore regional trading and settlement alliances and 
linkages and to remove regulatory and legal impediments to such linkages. ASEAN countries 
have worked closely together with the FTSE Group11 to develop an FTSE/ASEAN index that 
should promote cross-border equity products.   
 
8.  Through  discussions  with  Brunei  Darussalam,  Indonesia,  Malaysia,  Philippines, 
Singapore, and Thailand under the framework of the regional country strategy and program, 
ADB has been asked to provide TA to promote enhanced cooperation among regional equity 
                                                 
8  ADB. 2004. Technical Assistance for Regional Strengthening of Asian Financial Markets, Regional Capital Markets 
Report. Manila (TA 5985-REG).   
9  Consistent with their obligations as IOSCO members, regulators from the six participating countries have agreed to 
adopt the first 16 of the IOSCO principles of securities regulation. The first 13 principles promote (i) an independent 
and accountable regulator, (ii) clear and consistent regulatory processes, (iii) comprehensive inspection and 
investigation powers of regulators along with comprehensive enforcement powers, (iv) credible use of such 
powers, (v) authority of the regulator to share public and nonpublic information with domestic and foreign 
counterparts,  (vi)  establishment  of  related  information  sharing  mechanisms,  and  (vii)  assistance  to  foreign 
regulators who need to make inquiries to discharge their regulatory functions. The remaining three principles 
promote (i) full, timely, and accurate disclosure of material information; (ii) fair and equitable treatment of 
shareholders; and (iii) high and internationally accepted accounting and auditing standards. 
10 Applicable laws and/or regulatory systems in the six participating countries generally do not provide a framework 
for the sharing of both public and nonpublic information among regional regulators. The current legal frameworks in 
Indonesia and Philippines require amendment to enable full cooperation in this area.

program  which  is  currently  being  prepared.  It  will  complement  other  ADB  initiatives  and 
incorporates findings and lessons learned from ADB’s work in capital markets in Southeast 
Asia, including related ADB loans, country specific TA, and regional TA, and other initiatives

collaborate in designing and implementing the TA. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The  TA  aims  to  support  the  development  of  Southeast  Asian  equity  markets.  The 
outcome of the Project will be better cooperation among equity markets through the adoption 
and  implementation  of  new  initiatives  and  action  plans  to  remove  legal,  regulatory,  and 
supervisory constraints to cross-border capital raising and trading. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Based on earlier work to develop capital markets in participating countries, and through 
dialogue with key stakeholders, surveys will be undertaken to clarify the supply and demand for 
regional equity products and the cost of equity capital raising and trading. Reviews will be 
undertaken to clarify initiatives being undertaken by ASEAN, the IOSCO Asia Pacific Regional 
Committee (APRC), and participating countries to address legal, regulatory and supervisory 
constraints to cross-border equity flows and related investor protection concerns. The reviews 
will identify gaps in current initiatives and make proposals that will complement ASEAN and 
APRC initiatives and promote harmonization of legal, regulatory, and supervisory frameworks. 
These will be discussed with key stakeholders and agreed to by the participating countries. The 
design  of  the  Project  will  be  flexible  so  it  can  respond  to  key  stakeholder  concerns  and 
proposals.13  Consultations  will  be  held  with  key  stakeholders,  particularly  with  ASEAN 
committees and task forces, APRC members, capital market regulators, and major market 
players.  
 
11.  The Project will: 
 
(i)  assess supply and demand for regional equity products, including potential cross- 
border investment products, and the cost of raising and trading equity products in 
participating countries; 
(ii)  review legal, regulatory and supervisory constraints to cross-border capital raising, 
and  trading  and  settlement  of  equity  products;  the  initiatives  that  have  been 
undertaken to address constraints; and make recommendations to fill any gaps; 
(iii)  review the status of enforcement frameworks, information-sharing agreements, and 
frameworks  for  investor  recourse  to  cross-border  dispute  resolution  and  make 
recommendations to fill any gaps; and 
(iv)  evaluate  and  help  facilitate  the  adoption  of  new  initiatives  by  the  participating 
countries  to  improve  cooperation  by  their  equity  markets  in  the  area  of  legal,

C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The total cost of the Project is estimated at $500,000 equivalent. ADB will finance the 
entire  cost.14  However,  each  participating  country  is  expected  facilitate  the  collection  of 
information and data available within the government. The Project will be financed by ADB on a 
grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. It will cover the costs of engaging consultants and 
preparing reports. The Project will also finance regional workshops and seminars to disseminate 
its findings, gather views on the feasibility of its proposals, and facilitate agreement on new 
initiatives and actions. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  ADB  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  Project  and will  administer  the  surveys, 
reviews, seminars, and workshops. Given that the Project will cover five countries under the 
Southeast Asian Department (SERD) and one country under the Mekong Department (MKRD), 
it will be executed by SERD in close coordination with MKRD and the Office of Regional 
Economic Integration (OREI). With the assistance of a team of consultants, ADB staff will work 
with ASEAN working groups and task forces, APRC, capital market regulators in participating 
countries, and other key stakeholders. The Project will be implemented over 10 months, from 
February  2006  to  November  2006.  Consulting  services  will  consist  of  two  international 
consultants (total 7.5 person-months): a regional capital market development expert will act as 
the team leader on an intermittent basis (5 person-months) and a capital market legal and 
regulatory  expert  (2.5  person  months).  Domestic  consultants  (total  26  person-months)  will 
include (i) a capital market development policy expert and project administrator (7 person-
months); (ii) a capital market statistical database expert (3 person-months) and country-specific 
experts from the participating countries who will be engaged for a total of 16 person-months. 
 
14.  The consultants will be engaged on an individual basis by ADB in accordance with 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
engagement  of  domestic  consultants.  The  team  leader  and  the  capital  market  legal  and 
regulatory expert will develop initial work plans that identify areas where local expertise is 
needed.  They  will  help  prepare  draft  terms  of  reference  for  recruitment  of  the  domestic 
consultants.  The  project  administrator  will  help  the  team  leader  and  ADB  coordinate  the 
activities of the consultants, including organization of the workshops and seminars and the 
timely submission of reports. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 4. 
All procurement of equipment and materials, and service payments under the Project will be in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Supporting Enhanced Cooperation among Southeast Asian Equity Markets, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Regional Capital Market Development Expert and Team Leader (5 person- 
months) 
1.  The team leader is expected to have significant expertise in developing capital markets 
in both developed and emerging markets, including experience in promoting linkages among 
capital markets. Experience in the Southeast Asia region is preferable.  The team leader will 
work closely with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) committees and task 
forces,  the  Asia  Pacific  Regional  Committee  (APRC)  of  the  International  Organization  of 
Securities Commissions (IOSCO), capital market regulators from the six countries participating 
in the Project, and major market players.  The team leader will develop new initiatives and 
action  plans  to  address  policy,  legal,  regulatory,  and  supervisory  impediments  to  regional 
market equity flows and will propose a role for ADB in supporting these new initiatives.  The 
team leader’s duties will include the following. 
   
(i)  With inputs from the international capital market legal and regulatory expert, and 
domestic experts design, organize, and oversee implementation, and analyze 
findings from surveys assessing supply and demand for regional equity products 
and transaction costs in capital raising and trading in the region.   
(ii)  With assistance from the project administrator, prepare draft terms of reference 
for domestic capital market experts who will undertake the surveys. 
(iii)  Taking  into  account  macroeconomic  and  political  factors  that  constrain 
development of capital markets in participating countries, and based on findings 
and recommendations of the capital market legal and regulatory expert regarding 
legal, regulatory and supervisory constraints to cross border offering and trading 
of equity products, ongoing initiatives and gaps in such initiatives, propose new 
initiatives and actions and facilitate adoption of these new initiatives and actions 
by participating countries and by ASEAN. 
(iv)  Participate in consultations with various stakeholders on findings and proposed 
recommendations. 
(v)  With the assistance of the capital market legal and regulatory expert, domestic 
capital market statistical database expert, and other domestic experts, develop 
benchmarks  to  track  progress  in  capital  market  development  and  regional 
cooperation  among  the  equity  markets  in  the  participating  countries,  and 
supervise the design and implementation of a database to track such indicators. 
(vi)  With the assistance of the international capital market legal and regulatory expert 
and  project  administrator,  oversee  organization  of  regional  workshops  and 
seminars, to present study and review findings and discuss recommendations 
and action plans. 
(vii)  With the assistance of the project administrator and capital market legal and 
regulatory expert, prepare a consolidated inception, interim and final report and 
updates at least every 2 months: 
(a)  inception report to be submitted by the end of the fourth week since the 
beginning of the Project, to present a preliminary framework of the studies 
and detailed work plans; 
(b)  interim report within 5 months of TA inception to clarify the status of 
deliverables under related workplans and outstanding issues; 
(c)  draft final report to be submitted 1 month before TA completion, to include 
clarification  of  demand  for  regional  equity  products,  policy,  legal,

(viii)  Represent  and/or  join  ADB  staff  in  international  and  local  conferences,  in 
meetings with ASEAN, APRC, capital market regulators from the six participating 
countries, and other key stakeholders to discuss regional cooperation among 
equity markets, as and when requested. 
 
2.  Capital Market Legal and Regulatory Expert (2.5 person-months)  
2.  The expert is expected to have significant experience in capital market regulation in 
developed and developing markets and working knowledge of the implementation of IOSCO 
best practice principles and objectives of securities regulation, including benchmarks under the 
IOSCO  multilateral  memorandum  of  understanding  and  cooperation.  Experience  in  the  six 
participating countries is preferable. The expert’s duties will include the following: 
 
(i)  In  coordination  with  the  team  leader,  design,  organize  and  oversee  the 
framework for legal, regulatory and supervisory reviews and recommendations. 
Reviews  shall  include  legal,  regulatory  and  supervisory  constraints  to  cross 
border offering and trading of equity capital, including identification of gaps in 
related  frameworks  for  cross  border  enforcement  and  dispute  resolution,  in 
participating  countries.  Enforcement  review  should  also  include  a  review  of 
related sanctions available.   
(ii)  In coordination with the team leader and project administrator, prepare draft 
terms of reference for domestic capital market regulatory and legal experts who 
will undertake the reviews. 
(iii)  With the assistance of the project administrator, supervise the implementation of 
the reviews. 
(iv)  With  the  support  of  domestic  consultants,  summarize  and  analyze 
recommendations  and  actions  taken  by  the  ASEAN  Capital  Market  Forum, 
APRC, and other bodies, including capital market regulators and institutions in 
the  participating  countries  to  promote  regional  cooperation  in  equity  market 
development. Focus on legal, regulatory and supervisory harmonization, and 
cross  border  enforcement  and  dispute  resolution,  and  assess  the  initiatives 
adopted and actions that have been taken. 
(v)  Prepare a report summarizing findings and making recommendations to promote 
legal,  regulatory  and  supervisory  harmonization  and  enhanced  investor 
protection. 
(vi)  Provide the team leader with executive summaries and reports as and when 
requested. 
(vii)  Support the team leader in all matters relating to capital market laws, regulations 
and enforcement. 
(viii)  Assist the team leader to organize the regional workshops and seminars. 
(ix)  Prepare interim and final report for the team leader in a form acceptable to the 
team leader.

B.  Domestic Consultants 
1.  Domestic  Capital  Market  Development  Policy  Expert  and  Project 
Administrator (7 person-months) 
3.  The  expert  should  have  significant  experience  working  in  Southeast  Asian  capital 
markets on development policy issues and experience in management of development-funded 
projects, including organization of international workshop and seminars. The expert’s duties will 
include the following: 
(i)  Assist the team leader to oversee project implementation and handle day-to-day 
administrative and logistical issues. 
(ii)  In coordination with the team leader and capital market legal and regulatory 
expert, prepare an inception report, including a work plan, interim report, draft 
final report and final report consolidating work from other experts. 
(iii)  In close coordination with the team leader and capital market legal and regulatory 
expert, help develop terms of reference for the domestic capital market experts 
and help identify qualified candidates. 
(iv)  Support team leader and capital market legal and regulatory expert to gather 
information and data, and perform related research. 
(v)  Oversee organization of seminars and workshops, including coordination of all 
logistics, preparation of budgets in line with ADB requirements, recruitment of 
highly  respected  facilitators,  hotel  bookings,  and  organization  of  workshop 
materials. 
(vi)  Join  the  team  leader  and  the  capital  market  legal  and  regulatory  expert  in 
meetings as and when requested.  
 
2.  Domestic Capital Market Experts (16 person-months) 
4.  Domestic  capital  market  development  experts  are  expected  to  have  significant 
experience in the capital markets of the participating countries, including product development, 
trading technologies, legal and regulatory frameworks, and dispute resolution frameworks. The 
experts should have a proven track record of promoting reforms, good analytical skills and 
understanding of the country, and experience dealing with government authorities. The expert’s 
duties will include the following: 
 
(i)  Under  the  supervision  of  the  team  leader  and/or  capital  market  legal  and 
regulatory expert, and in coordination with the project administrator, undertake 
surveys and reviews and prepare country reports as identified in the experts' 
terms of reference (to be defined by the team leader and the international capital 
market legal and regulatory expert).  
(ii)  In coordination with the team leader, capital market legal and regulatory expert 
and/or project administrator, prepare work plans with specific responsibilities. 
(iii)  Participate in discussions with officials and representatives of ASEAN, APRC, 
capital  market  regulators  from  the  six  participating  countries,  representatives 
from market institutions, and other key stakeholders. 
(iv)  Join  the  team  leader  and/or  capital  market  legal  and  regulatory  expert  in 
meetings as and when requested. 
(v)  Participate in regional seminars and workshops. 
(vi)  Assist the team leader and project administrator to organize regional workshops. 
(vii)  Prepare a final report in a form acceptable to the team leader.

12  Appendix 4 
3.  Capital Markets Statistical Database Expert (3 person months) 
5.  The expert should have significant experience designing databases for financial sector 
regulators, be familiar with statistical information on domestic financial/capital markets in the six 
participating  countries,  with  a  focus  on  equity  markets,  and  experience  in  dealing  with 
government authorities. The expert will support the team leader in developing benchmarks and 
will develop and populate a database to track progress in capital market development and 
regional cooperation in equity markets in the participating countries.
